feed.title: Medialytics Releases
feed.subtitle: Self-hosted software releases generated by selfh.st

entry.title: New release for Medialytics: v2.2
entry.content:
• Now tracking watched/unwatched status across total library, as well as within genre, studio, country, and decades charts

Full Changelog: https://github.com/Drewpeifer/medialytics/compare/v2.1.2...v2.2

entry.title: New release for Medialytics: v2.2.1
entry.content:
Version bump to troubleshoot workflow actions, no changes from previous version

Full Changelog: https://github.com/Drewpeifer/medialytics/compare/v2.2...v2.2.1

entry.title: New release for Medialytics: v2.3
entry.content: This release adds charts that track resolution and container (file type), for movies only:

entry.title: New release for Medialytics: v2.3.5
entry.content:
v2.3.5 - Ratings + Writers

New Features: - Scatter chart of audienceRating (TMDB) VS contentRating including highest rated and lowest rated - Built with plotly.js, so there are custom controls (zoom, pan, select) not present for other charts - Highest / lowest rated should display the first encountered item with a particular rating, if there are multiple - Bar chart for contentRatings + top contentRating - Bar chart for items by writer + top writer (movies only) - Watched/unwatched percentage is now visible in tooltip for bar charts - Shuffled some cards around in the UI - Charts that were previously pie-only now support bar as well

Fixes / Maintenance: - BUG - Added missing "top" counts for resolution and container - BUG - Items with multiple actors and directors were only counting the first one, e.g. a movie with directors = ["Joel Coen", "Ethan Coen"] would only increment the count for Joel - BUG - In the items by decades chart, the decades (x axis) were reordering and not displaying properly when switching between libraries - BUG - Decades chart now always sorts by the most recent decade when updating the limit (so updating to 3 will reduce it to [2020, 2010, 2000] regardless of the decade with the highest count). Previously it was inconsistent. - MAINT - Better consolidation of CSS, still a WIP - MAINT - Made aggregation logic more consistent across the board - MAINT - Consolidated aggregation logic into library-agnostic and library-specific blocks - MAINT - Removed some redundant variables - MAINT - Better flex behavior for several items
